Award.AwardTitle: High power GaInAs photoconductive terahertz radiation source

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: Our objective is the development of a compact sub-picosecond THz-radiation source for time-domain (TD) THz spectroscopy and THz-imaging with an average power of 1mW operating at MHz repetition rates.

Intellectual merit: The approach utilizes voltage-biased THz-emitters made from ternary and quaternary alloyed semiconductors driven by multi watt mode-locked Ytterbium (Yb) lasers. Unique crystal growth by Vertical Bridgman and Vertical Gradient Freezing Methods with accelerated crucible rotation technique will be used to produce crystals with high-resistivity (104-107?Çcm), high-mobility (3000-5000 cm2/Vs) and femtosecond carrier lifetimes as well as variable band gaps between 0.4eV to 1.5eV. Materials grown from melt will provide superior electrical and optical properties due to the near-equilibrium growth process compared to thin films grown from vapor or solid phases. The energy band gap of ternary and quaternary alloyed semiconductors can be perfectly matched to the emission wavelengths of Yb-lasers in the 1000-1100nm band.

Broader impact: The proposed research integrates research and education through curriculum enhancement as well as undergraduate and graduate students¡¦ research participation. Outreach to undergraduate students from non-PhD-granting institutions will be practiced through a summer REU program. Another strong focus will be outreach to minorities underrepresented in science and engineering and recruiting of these students for our research. The proposed research will advance applications of time-domain THz- spectroscopy and imaging in research and industries across a broad range of disciplines through brighter emitters and compact THz-systems. Time-domain THz technology will be one key application of multi watt mode-locked Ytterbium lasers in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: The outcome of this project are semiconductor materials with superior electronic properties for the fabrication of photoconducting sources of terahertz frequency electromagnetic radiation with terahertz radiation power higher than the state-of-the-art. In particular, iron-doped gallium-indium-arsenide compound semiconductor crystals with an electron band gap of 1 eV, an electron mobility of 2395 cm2/Vs, photocarrier lifetime of 306 fs and resistivities of 107 Ohm cm have been realized. The highest observed terahertz radiation power emitted by the semiconductor materials was 8 microwatts when the terahertz radiation emission was stimulated by near-infrared femtosecond laser pulses from a titanium sapphire laser.

Broader impact: The outcome of this project supports the feasibility of photoconducting terahertz radiation sources with terahertz radiation power at milliwatt power levels. This is important because the demand for photoconducting terahertz radiation sources has increased recently and is expected to remain strong in the future. The limitation of low terahertz radiation power in photoconductive terahertz radiation sources in terahertz spectroscopy systems is still a major problem for applications of the technique. The interest in terahertz spectroscopy in chemistry, materials science and engineering is growing. This drives the need for compact, powerful, easy-to-use and cost-effective instrumentation. The development of semiconductor materials with energy band gaps suitable for operation with femtosecond lasers emitting between 1000nm and 1600nm wavelengths as achieved in this project is important for the development of terahertz spectrometers which meet the described needs.

Also, the project resulted in science, technology and workforce development by providing high-quality research training to a total of nineteen undergraduate and graduate students across multiple disciplines, e.g. physics, electrical, chemical and mechanical engineering. Students were trained hands-on in semiconductor crystal growth, terahertz radiation measurements, data analysis and acquired presentation skills.  Furthermore, the principal investigators fostered highschool students' interest in science and engineering by mentoring highschool students' research project and serving as judge at the regional science fair.
